column1: from a carousel at one end and delivers finished sleeves at the other. [SEP] One operator can tend to the needs of two such machines. [SEP] Yet because the investment per worker is several hundred thousand dollars, it only makes sense if the equipment is used nearly continuously. [SEP] Sewing factories, in contrast, are not capital intensive and are rarely operated for more than one shift. [SEP] Because of this, most expensive automation equipment is concentrated in preassembly, drawing on multi-shift operations. [SEP] Marker-making, fusing processes, sleeve-making for T-shirts, die-cutting, and computer-driven knife-cutting fall into this automated “getting ready to sew” category. [SEP] As always in a world of lean retailing and rapid replenishment, the need for faster production is what
column3: these capital-intensive technical innovations. [SEP] Because some U.S. manufacturers have found that centralizing preassembly operations also improves the quality of products, this may provide another edge for American apparel-makers in the future. [SEP] Our survey indicates that the average length of time it takes to get a garment ready for sewing, from issuing the order for a given marker to having the pieces cut and otherwise prepared, is 4.9 working days. [SEP] The cut parts are then sent to sewing areas or other factories. [SEP] If the sewing room is in the same building as the cutting room, then cut goods are sent over many times a day. [SEP] If the sewing factory is far away, then a shipment once a week is typical. [SEP] Reducing the time from placement of the order to cut goods in t

column1: Low Rider The expression “low rider” is used to describe the car, the subculture, and the person who
column3: a vehicle that has been lowered, rides very low, and has been customized. [SEP] A car, truck, bicycle, van, or motorcycle that has been lowered—and this can be achieved by various methods—means that it sits very close to the ground and has a sleek streamlined appearance. [SEP] The driver and/or owner is called a low rider and the act of low riding refers to all the activities associated with driving the car: cruising, caravanning, and hopping. [SEP] Low riders have commonly been associated with cholos (1990s urban youth) and gangs, but traditionally Chicanos seriously involved in low riding and customizing low-rider cars are not involved in gangs, and low-rider clubs actually present an alternative to gang involvement. [SEP] Given that the dimensionality of the adjacent possible of the biosphere has expanded in the past . [SEP] billion years, I want to make the obvious conjecture at a law: Our biosphere and any biosphere expands the dimensionality of its adjacent possible, on average, as rapidly as it can. [SEP] I will return just below to think about bounds on this expansion. [SEP] For, as we will see, it seems reasonable that if the expansion were too rapid, the system would destroy the propagating organization of autonomous agents whose coevolution and increasing diversity is what
column3: expansion into the adjacent possible and tends secularly to increase that dimensionality. [SEP] Autonomous agents persistently stumble onto new ways of making a living with one another and exploit those new ways. [SEP] The biosphere’s advance into the adjacent possible is just exaptation over and over again. [SEP] In fact, it seems reasonable to think of the “workspace” of the biosphere, that is, what can happen next, as its actual plus its real adjacent possible. [SEP] It seems likely, and I do conjecture, that the biosphere is expanding its workspace, on average, as fast as it can do so without destroying itself in the process.

Before turning back to biology, it is essential to stress that the results noted above for synchronous Boolean networks extend to asynchronous Boolean networks and, more critically, extend to a family of model gene networks in which the genes have graded levels of activity. This is important because the on-o Boolean idealization is quite severe. column1: logical development of the art form. [SEP] Simply styled male and female figures (kouros and kore) of the Achaiac Age (seventh–fifth century b.c.) give way to more ornate and literal human forms as you walk through the collection into the Classical Age and then on to the Hellenistic and Roman eras. [SEP] Greek gods are popular themes, followed by eminent human figures of Roman times. [SEP] Room 7 holds the important early statue of Artemis by Nikandre of Naxos (c640 b.c.). [SEP] Room 15 is dominated by a fine statue of Poseidon in bronze (460 b.c.) found in the sea off the island of Euboea. [SEP] The god is set to launch his trident against foes unknown. [SEP] The Hall of the Stairs hosts another statue dredged from the sea, that of the Jockey of the Artemision. [SEP] The diminutive jockey
column3: on the handsome steed which has its two front legs raised into the air, as if about to leap over an invisible obstacle. [SEP] Rooms 36–39 have a collection of bronzes including votive offerings found at the Idaean Cave in Crete — mythical birthplace of the god Zeus. [SEP] Rooms 40 and 41 display artifacts from Egypt covering every era of history in the land of the Pharaohs, including the Ptolemaic period when Ptolemy (a general under Alexander the Great, and therefore of Greek descent) took control of Egypt. [SEP] One of his descendants was Cleopatra, perhaps this most famous ancient queen.

column1: While you’re on the north side of town, take a drive around the Hollywood Hills for a superb view of the city. [SEP] The classic Los Angeles cruise is along Mulholland Drive. [SEP] On a clear day you can see Long Beach, 25-miles (40-km) away across the vast, sprawling metropolis. [SEP] Another great viewpoint is the Observatory in Griffith Park (off Highway 5). [SEP] Fans of James Dean will recognize the Observatory — it was the scene of the climax of Rebel Without a Cause. [SEP] The panorama from the terrace on a clear day is fantastic, from the spiky skyscrapers of downtown to the distant Pacific. [SEP] Griffith Park is the biggest city park in the United States. [SEP] It sprawls across the eastern Hollywood Hills and is criss-crossed with
column3: and hiking trails. [SEP] Toward sunset is the best time to go, just as the city lights are coming on. [SEP] Westside

column1: After potatoes (winning P.E.I. the name of “Spud Island,” a less grandiloquent alternative to “Cradle of Confederation”), tourism rates as the number two industry. [SEP] The superb sandy beaches of the north coast attract over half a million visitors a year. column1: Golf and Tennis Golf. [SEP] The area from Punta Mita on the northern tip of Banderas Bay to Manzanillo in the south is beginning to rival Los Cabos as Mexico’s golf mecca. [SEP] Six exceptional golf courses are located here, notable not only for their challenging designs coupled, with ocean and jungle views, but also for their absence of crowds and reasonable prices. [SEP] The newest is the Jack Nicklaus–designed course at the Four Seasons Punta Mita (Tel. [SEP] (3) 291-6000) located 30 minutes north of Puerto Vallarta, notable for a spectacular hole that
column3: to a natural island 175 yards offshore. [SEP] Currently, it is open only to guests of the Four Seasons, or members of other golf clubs with a letter of introduction. [SEP] Two other courses are located near Puerto Vallarta: Club de Golf Flamingos (Tel. [SEP] (3) 298-0606), a casual course open to the public, and the Joe Finger–designed course at the Marina Vallarta Golf Club (Tel. [SEP] (3) 221-0073). [SEP] Four new courses are scheduled to open in the surrounding area by mid 2001. [SEP] Traveling south along the Costa Alegre, two spectacular courses offer exclusive play and multiple ocean views.
